Cancer Classification on BCR

Back To Projects
GitHub

Introduction

Understanding B-cell receptor repertoire from amino acid sequence is a fundamental problem in biology. In this project, we explore how well we can classify B-cell immunoglobulin repertoires into cancer types through examination of raw sequence. Using a large corpus of B-cell receptor repertoire sequencing fragments and their associated cancer types, we learn dense vector representations for amino acid sequences using the co-occurrence statistics of short fragments or/and fragments classification. Then, using this representation, we experiment with several neural network architectures to train classifiers for cancer types identification. We show good performance for a multi-class prediction problem with 4241 patients reports and 13 different cancer types. In addition, we also build model to predict each patient’s survival outcome and overall survival days.

Implementation

Next-generation sequencing technologies generate large amounts of biological sequence information in the form of DNA/RNA sequences. From DNA sequences we also know the amino acid sequences of proteins, which are the fundamental molecules that perform most biological functions. High-throughput sequencing of B-cell immunoglobulin repertoires (BCR) is increasingly being applied to gain insights into the adaptive immune response in healthy individuals and in those with a wide range of diseases. Recent applications include the study of autoimmunity, infection, allergy, cancer and aging. As sequencing technologies continue to improve, these repertoire sequencing experiments are producing ever larger datasets. These data require specialized bioinformatics pipelines to be analyzed effectively. These include methods for unique molecular identifiers and sequencing error correction, V(D)J assignment and detection of novel alleles, clonal assignment, lineage tree construction, somatic hypermutation modeling, selection analysis, and analysis of stereotyped or convergent responses. The functionality of BCR is thus encoded in the amino acid sequence and understanding the sequence-function relationship is a major challenge in bioinformatics.
As we have learnt from the dataset, we have only 4,241 samples but with 12,934,656 sequences fregements and 5,960,182 unique sequences are among them. These sequences are lengths from zero to dozens. It is obvious that we can not use all these variations as features for modeling and training. There are too much capacity and too many variables, which are easy lead to overfitting. Feature Selection and Extraction are the most important part in this project. We have tried clustering sequences without considering any domain knowledge, then predict cancer types using clustered sequences as features. Sequence clustering of amino acid sequences of varying lengths, specifically Ward’s method a general agglomerative hierarchical clustering procedure, was chosen. Our second idea is to do feature selection and extraction using a similar method from natural language processing concept. In addition we try to lower the dimension by clustering the amino acids with some domain knowledge. “Bag-of-amino-acids” model. In natural language processing and information retrieval, the bag-of-words model or vector space model is used to simplify text representation, as a commonly used method of document classification. Here we build a “bag-of-amino-acids” model as a tool of feature generation.

Highlight

Introduced NPL N-gram model into bioinformatics.
TensorFlow with GPU.

Achievement

In sum, by random guessing, our problem will have a base a accuracy of 8%. Unigram or clustering unigram can not have the accuracy above the random guessing. Bigram or clustering bigram will increase the accuracy to 20%. When apply trigram or clustering trigram, the accuracy can reach 30%. Combine trigram and clustering trigram will achieve 35%. All features combined will have the most optimized accuracy of 40%.
